misconceptions.name: Implemented an unrelated physics formula instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program is solving a different problem (computing average acceleration from v0, v1, and t) rather than reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to compute the average acceleration given initial velocity, final velocity, and time, and that this is an appropriate solution for the assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check each for evenness, accumulate the sum of the even numbers only, and then print that sum with an appropriate message (e.g., "Sum of even numbers: X").
symptoms: Prompt asks for v0, v1, and t instead of 5 integers
Program computes (v1 - v0) / t instead of any kind of sum
Output message mentions "average acceleration" rather than "sum of even numbers"
No logic exists for checking whether numbers are even or for accumulating a sum
misconceptions.root_cause: Most likely confusion with or reuse of a different textbook/example problem about average acceleration, rather than implementing the specified sum-of-evens algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the current physics-specific logic and redesign the algorithm: 1) read 5 integers, 2) for each integer, if it is even (n % 2 == 0) add it to a running sum, 3) after processing all 5 numbers, print the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompts, variable names, and formula exactly match a standard average-acceleration exercise and do not relate at all to summing even numbers.

evidence.note: These lines show the program computing average acceleration, with no mention of reading 5 integers, checking evenness, or summing values.

misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program reads only three double values (v0, v1, t) and never reads five integers as required by the problem statement.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that reading three double values with nextDouble for v0, v1, and t is suitable input handling for this task.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use nextInt (or equivalent) to read exactly five integer values from the user, since the specification explicitly calls for 5 integers.
symptoms: Only three calls to nextDouble are present
No use of nextInt or any loop to read 5 integers
Prompt text asks for three values instead of five integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Misalignment between the problem specification and the implemented input pattern, likely due to copying from a different example that expects three doubles.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the three nextDouble calls with input logic that reads five integers, e.g., using a loop that calls nextInt five times and stores or processes each value.
related_concepts: Matching input handling to problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly reads three doubles and never attempts to read any additional values or use integers, which directly contradicts the requirement.

evidence.snippet:

double v0=s.nextDouble(),v1=s.nextDouble(),t=s.nextDouble();
evidence.note: Shows that the program reads exactly three double inputs, not five integers as specified.

misconceptions.name: Missing even-number conditional check
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even (no use of n % 2 == 0 or equivalent), so it cannot filter or selectively sum only even numbers as required.
